question_details.query: When restoring grasslands, how do the outcomes of simply disturbing the soil before seeding compare to removing the topsoil entirely?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
A replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that removing turf before sowing seeds increased grass and forb species richness in most cases compared to disturbing the soil before sowing [3415]. In France, one replicated, randomized, controlled study found that removing topsoil before sowing seeds increased plant community similarity to that of an intact steppe and also increased plant species richness [3415]. A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK also found that removing topsoil before planting seedlings led to a higher cover of the planted species [3415]. Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that removing topsoil before planting or sowing increased the survival of seedlings and plants [3415].

For soil disturbance, one of two replicated, controlled studies in the UK and Germany found that disturbing the soil before sowing seeds increased plant and seedling species richness, while the other study found no change [3413]. A study in the USA found that disturbing the soil before sowing forb seeds increased the cover of forb species [3413]. Four of five replicated, controlled studies found that disturbing the soil before sowing seeds increased plant emergence in most cases compared to sowing alone [3413]. One of two replicated, controlled studies found that disturbing the soil before sowing increased the survival of seedlings [3413].

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of adding soil amendments like charcoal, sulphur, or carbon before or after seeding on grassland vegetation?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available documentation, the effects of adding soil amendments like charcoal, sulphur, or carbon before or after seeding on grassland vegetation are varied.

Two studies in the USA found that adding carbon to the soil after sowing seeds either reduced or did not change the density of sown forb species (3433). A study in the Netherlands showed that adding charcoal to the soil before sowing did not change overall plant biomass or grass cover, but it did increase the cover of legumes while not affecting other forbs (3422).

The effects of adding sulphur are conflicting. One study in the UK and USA found that adding sulphur before sowing seeds reduced plant species richness, while another found no change (3428). Similarly, one study found it reduced overall vegetation cover (3428), while another found that low amounts of sulphur increased the cover of three of six sown species (3428). One study found that adding it alongside sowing had mixed effects on the cover of common heather, perennial rye-grass and common bent (1710), and another found it did not increase heather cover in most cases (1710). However, a different study showed that it increased the survival of planted heather seedlings, though survival after two years was very low (1710). Another study found that adding sulphur to a former agricultural field did not increase the number of heather seedlings (1691).
summary_statements: The effects of adding soil amendments like charcoal, sulphur, or carbon before or after seeding on grassland vegetation are varied.
Two studies in the USA found that adding carbon to the soil after sowing seeds either reduced or did not change the density of sown forb species.
A study in the Netherlands showed that adding charcoal to the soil before sowing did not change overall plant biomass or grass cover.
A study in the Netherlands showed that adding charcoal to the soil before sowing increased the cover of legumes.
Adding charcoal to the soil before sowing did not affect other forbs in a study in the Netherlands.
The effects of adding sulphur are conflicting.
One study in the UK and USA found that adding sulphur before sowing seeds reduced plant species richness.
Another study found that adding sulphur before sowing seeds resulted in no change to plant species richness.
One study found that adding sulphur reduced overall vegetation cover.
Another study found that low amounts of sulphur increased the cover of three of six sown species.
One study found that adding sulphur alongside sowing had mixed effects on the cover of common heather, perennial rye-grass and common bent.
Another study found that adding sulphur did not increase heather cover in most cases.
A different study showed that adding sulphur increased the survival of planted heather seedlings.
In one study, the survival of planted heather seedlings after two years was very low.
A study found that adding sulphur to a former agricultural field did not increase the number of heather seedlings.

question_details.query: What are the potential negative impacts on native vegetation of sowing grass seeds at high densities in the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In the USA, sowing grass seeds at higher densities can reduce the cover of native grassland shrubs (3405). Other studies in the USA on sowing grass seeds have shown a reduction in native grass cover and the abundance of native forb species (3397). The abundance of shrub species has also been found to be reduced (3397). Additionally, sowing grass seeds has been found to result in lower species richness compared to nearby intact prairies (3397). It was also found that even when sowing native grass and forbs, species richness was lower in sown areas than in nearby intact grasslands (3432). Sowing grass seeds did not alter the species richness of native plants in one study (3397).
summary_statements: In the USA, sowing grass seeds at higher densities can reduce the cover of native grassland shrubs.
Studies in the USA on sowing grass seeds have shown a reduction in native grass cover.
Studies in the USA on sowing grass seeds have shown a reduction in the abundance of native forb species.
The abundance of shrub species has been found to be reduced by sowing grass seeds.
Sowing grass seeds has been found to result in lower species richness compared to nearby intact prairies.
Even when sowing native grass and forbs, species richness was lower in sown areas than in nearby intact grasslands.
Sowing grass seeds did not alter the species richness of native plants in one study.

question_details.query: In European grasslands, how does post-seeding management by mowing compare to livestock grazing for enhancing sown species?

summary_details.relevant_summary: I am sorry, but after a thorough search, I was unable to find any information that directly compares the effectiveness of post-seeding management by mowing versus livestock grazing for enhancing sown species in European grasslands.
summary_statements: No information was found that directly compares the effectiveness of post-seeding management by mowing versus livestock grazing for enhancing sown species in European grasslands.

question_details.query: What does the evidence show about the effectiveness of different site preparation methods for improving the survival of seeded or planted species?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Six of seven studies, which included five replicated, randomized, controlled studies, in Canada and Sweden revealed that ground preparation treatments enhanced the survival and growth rate of planted trees (1263). However, one study indicated that creating mounds had no impact on frost damage to planted Norway spruce seedlings (1263). Another study in Hungary found that sowing seeds in large gaps within vegetation resulted in a greater cover of sown target plant species compared to sowing in smaller gaps (3409). No studies were found that assessed the effects of protecting or preparing peatland vegetation before planting, apart from the addition of root-associated fungi (1842).
summary_statements: Six of seven studies in Canada and Sweden revealed that ground preparation treatments enhanced the survival and growth rate of planted trees.
One study indicated that creating mounds had no impact on frost damage to planted Norway spruce seedlings.
A study in Hungary found that sowing seeds in large gaps within vegetation resulted in a greater cover of sown target plant species compared to sowing in smaller gaps.
No studies were found that assessed the effects of protecting or preparing peatland vegetation before planting, apart from the addition of root-associated fungi.

question_details.query: How do the effects of sowing parasitic plants differ across European countries for restoring grassland vegetation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Five out of six studies in the UK, Switzerland, and Belgium showed that planting parasitic seeds like yellow rattle, European yellow rattle, or marsh lousewort led to an increase in plant species richness and/or diversity. The remaining study, however, revealed that sowing yellow rattle seeds did not change the variety of plant species (3404). According to a review conducted in the UK, planting yellow-rattle seeds resulted in a decrease in total plant biomass in three out of the four studies (3404). A study that was supervised in Belgium revealed that planting marsh lousewort seeds increased the population of the six desired plant species (3404). A study conducted in Switzerland that was both replicated and controlled revealed that planting seeds of the parasitic plant known as European yellow rattle resulted in a reduction in the amount of grass cover (3404). Nevertheless, the study also discovered that it did not affect the forb cover (3404).
summary_statements: Five out of six studies in the UK, Switzerland, and Belgium showed that planting parasitic seeds like yellow rattle, European yellow rattle, or marsh lousewort led to an increase in plant species richness and/or diversity.
One study revealed that sowing yellow rattle seeds did not change the variety of plant species.
According to a review conducted in the UK, planting yellow-rattle seeds resulted in a decrease in total plant biomass in three out of the four studies.
A study supervised in Belgium revealed that planting marsh lousewort seeds increased the population of the six desired plant species.
A replicated and controlled study conducted in Switzerland revealed that planting seeds of the parasitic plant known as European yellow rattle resulted in a reduction in the amount of grass cover.
A study in Switzerland also discovered that planting seeds of the parasitic plant known as European yellow rattle did not affect the forb cover.

question_details.query: How does drill seeding compare with hydroseeding for establishing sown species in the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that hydroseeding increased the abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding [3412]. In contrast, one of three replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that sowing seeds with a seed drill increased the density of two sown grass species compared to sowing by hand, while the other two studies found that in most cases sowing seeds with a seed drill led to no change or a reduction in the abundance of sown plants compared to hydroseeding or sowing by hand [3410]. Two of three replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that sowing seeds with a seed drill did not alter plant species richness [3410]. One replicated, paired, controlled study in the USA found that sowing grassland seeds with a seed drill increased the abundance of warm-season grass species compared to sowing by hand [3410].
summary_statements: A study in the USA found that hydroseeding increased the abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding.
One study in the USA found that sowing seeds with a seed drill increased the density of two sown grass species compared to sowing by hand.
Two other studies in the USA found that in most cases sowing seeds with a seed drill led to no change or a reduction in the abundance of sown plants compared to hydroseeding or sowing by hand.
Two studies in the USA found that sowing seeds with a seed drill did not alter plant species richness.
A study in the USA found that sowing grassland seeds with a seed drill increased the abundance of warm-season grass species compared to sowing by hand.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of adding soil amendments like mycorrhiza or topsoil prior to seeding?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding has shown varied results. One study found that it did not alter plant species richness (3429), while another found it increased the abundance of target species that were a local conservation priority (3429). Mycorrhizal inoculation was also found to increase the height of giant sacaton plants, but it did not increase their biomass or emergence (3429). Another study found that inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi before sowing seeds initially increased vegetation cover, but this effect was not present after three years (3429). There is no evidence for the effect of inoculating tree seedlings with mycorrhizae (1160).

Adding topsoil before seeding or planting has been shown to be beneficial in some cases. One study found that adding topsoil before sowing seeds increased plant species richness and the biomass of sown species in most cases (3420). Another study found that the addition of topsoil alongside sowing of seed increased the biomass of grasses but reduced the biomass of forbs when compared to the addition of topsoil alone (1857).

Other soil amendments have also been studied. Amending the soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers has been found to increase microbial biomass, activity, and diversity, as well as the amount of organic carbon in the soil and maize yield (902). The addition of fresh plant material or crop remains to the soil has been shown to increase microbial biomass and carbon levels, and in some cases, has led to a reduction in soil loss and an increase in crop yields (910). Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can reduce weed growth, but the effects can be variable and may not last long. The impact of these remains on crop growth and yield is mixed, with some studies showing inhibition and others showing positive effects (728).
summary_statements: Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding has shown varied results.
One study found that inoculating soil with mycorrhiza did not alter plant species richness.
Another study found that inoculating soil with mycorrhiza increased the abundance of target species that were a local conservation priority.
Mycorrhizal inoculation was found to increase the height of giant sacaton plants.
Mycorrhizal inoculation did not increase the biomass or emergence of giant sacaton plants.
Inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi before sowing seeds initially increased vegetation cover.
The initial increase in vegetation cover from inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi was not present after three years.
There is no evidence for the effect of inoculating tree seedlings with mycorrhizae.
Adding topsoil before seeding or planting has been shown to be beneficial in some cases.
Adding topsoil before sowing seeds increased plant species richness in most cases.
Adding topsoil before sowing seeds increased the biomass of sown species in most cases.
The addition of topsoil alongside the sowing of seed increased the biomass of grasses when compared to the addition of topsoil alone.
The addition of topsoil alongside the sowing of seed reduced the biomass of forbs when compared to the addition of topsoil alone.
Other soil amendments have also been studied.
Amending soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers has been found to increase microbial biomass, activity, and diversity.
Amending soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers has been found to increase the amount of organic carbon in the soil.
Amending soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers has been found to increase maize yield.
The addition of fresh plant material or crop remains to the soil has been shown to increase microbial biomass and carbon levels.
The addition of fresh plant material or crop remains to the soil has, in some cases, led to a reduction in soil loss.
The addition of fresh plant material or crop remains to the soil has, in some cases, led to an increase in crop yields.
Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can reduce weed growth.
The weed-reducing effects of incorporating certain plant remains can be variable and may not last long.
The impact of incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals on crop growth and yield is mixed.
Some studies show that incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can inhibit crop growth and yield.
Other studies show that incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can have positive effects on crop growth and yield.

question_details.query: In Europe, how does the effectiveness of sowing locally sourced seeds compare to sowing commercial seed mixes for improving plant species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A study in Italy found that sowing grassland seeds from a local source increased plant species richness compared to using a commercial seed mix (3400). Similarly, a study in Germany indicated that sowing locally sourced seeds, particularly when the number of species in the mix was increased, led to a greater richness of target plant species (3400, 3406). This approach in Germany also increased the cover of these target species (3406). Furthermore, another study in Germany showed that sowing seeds from a local source increased the abundance of one of the four sown characteristic plant species (3400). In the broader context of sowing native seeds in Europe, multiple studies have noted positive outcomes. Six out of nine studies in Europe found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the species richness of characteristic grassland plants (3432). Additionally, three studies in the UK and the Czech Republic reported an increase in the richness of sown species after sowing native grass and forbs (3432). Of twenty-eight studies conducted in Europe, North America, and New Zealand, sixteen found an increase in overall plant species richness from sowing native grass and forb seeds (3432).
summary_statements: A study in Italy found that sowing grassland seeds from a local source increased plant species richness compared to using a commercial seed mix.
A study in Germany indicated that sowing locally sourced seeds led to a greater richness of target plant species.
The increase in richness of target plant species from sowing locally sourced seeds in Germany was particularly notable when the number of species in the mix was increased.
Sowing locally sourced seeds in Germany also increased the cover of target plant species.
Another study in Germany showed that sowing seeds from a local source increased the abundance of one of the four sown characteristic plant species.
In the broader context of sowing native seeds in Europe, multiple studies have noted positive outcomes.
Six out of nine studies in Europe found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the species richness of characteristic grassland plants.
Three studies in the UK and the Czech Republic reported an increase in the richness of sown species after sowing native grass and forbs.
Of twenty-eight studies conducted in Europe, North America, and New Zealand, sixteen found an increase in overall plant species richness from sowing native grass and forb seeds.

question_details.query: When restoring grasslands, how does the effectiveness of drill seeding compare to hydroseeding or slot/strip seeding for establishing new plants?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
When comparing drill seeding to other methods, one of three replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that using a seed drill increased the density of two sown grass species compared to sowing by hand (3410). In contrast, two other studies in the USA found that drill seeding led to no change or a reduction in the abundance of sown plants compared to hydroseeding or sowing by hand (3410). A replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that hydroseeding increased the abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding (3412).

A replicated, paired, controlled study in the USA found that sowing grassland seeds with a seed drill increased the abundance of warm-season grass species compared to sowing by hand (3410). For slot/strip seeding, one review in the UK found that in the majority of cases, it resulted in failed introductions of sown species (3411). However, a replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that strip seeding increased both grass and forb species richness (3411).
summary_statements: One of three replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that using a seed drill increased the density of two sown grass species compared to sowing by hand.
Two other studies in the USA found that drill seeding led to no change in the abundance of sown plants compared to hydroseeding or sowing by hand.
Two other studies in the USA found that drill seeding led to a reduction in the abundance of sown plants compared to hydroseeding or sowing by hand.
A replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that hydroseeding increased the abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding.
A replicated, paired, controlled study in the USA found that sowing grassland seeds with a seed drill increased the abundance of warm-season grass species compared to sowing by hand.
One review in the UK found that in the majority of cases, slot/strip seeding resulted in failed introductions of sown species.
A replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that strip seeding increased grass species richness.
A replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that strip seeding increased forb species richness.

question_details.query: What does the evidence from different continents suggest about the effect of sowing grass seeds on native grass and forb abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Evidence from North America and Europe suggests that the effect of sowing grass seeds depends on whether native or non-native species are used. In North America (USA and Canada), three out of four studies found that sowing grass seeds either reduced native grass cover or did not alter native grass density (3397). Additionally, one of two studies in the USA and Canada found that sowing grass seeds reduced the abundance of native forb species (3397). However, one study in the USA found that sowing grass seeds did not alter the cover of native plant species (3397).

In contrast, studies from Europe and North America show more positive outcomes when native species are sown. Two out of three replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the Czech Republic and the USA revealed that sowing native grass and forbs increased the cover of grass species (3432). Similarly, three out of four studies from these regions found that the same action increased the cover or density of forb species (3432). One study in the USA also reported that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the cover of native plant species (3432).

Regarding sowing density, one study in the USA found that sowing seeds at a higher density increased both grass and forb cover (3405). Conversely, a site comparison study in the USA discovered that sowing grass seeds at a higher density led to a reduction in the cover of native grassland shrubs (3405).
summary_statements: Evidence from North America and Europe suggests that the effect of sowing grass seeds depends on whether native or non-native species are used.
In North America (USA and Canada), three out of four studies found that sowing grass seeds either reduced native grass cover or did not alter native grass density.
One of two studies in the USA and Canada found that sowing grass seeds reduced the abundance of native forb species.
One study in the USA found that sowing grass seeds did not alter the cover of native plant species.
Studies from Europe and North America show more positive outcomes when native species are sown.
Two out of three replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the Czech Republic and the USA revealed that sowing native grass and forbs increased the cover of grass species.
Three out of four studies from the Czech Republic and the USA found that sowing native grass and forbs increased the cover or density of forb species.
One study in the USA reported that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the cover of native plant species.
One study in the USA found that sowing seeds at a higher density increased both grass and forb cover.
A site comparison study in the USA discovered that sowing grass seeds at a higher density led to a reduction in the cover of native grassland shrubs.

question_details.query: What are the potential negative or neutral effects of adding amendments like mulch or carbon to the soil when seeding grasslands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In two studies in the USA, adding carbon to the soil after seeding either reduced or did not change the density of sown forb species (3433). In a study in the Netherlands, adding charcoal to the soil before seeding did not alter the overall plant biomass or grass cover, but did increase the cover of legumes (3422). No studies were found that looked at the effects of using organic mulch to restore or create freshwater marshes, freshwater swamps, or brackish/saline swamps (3247, 3249, 3250).
summary_statements: In two studies in the USA, adding carbon to the soil after seeding reduced the density of sown forb species.
In two studies in the USA, adding carbon to the soil after seeding did not change the density of sown forb species.
In a study in the Netherlands, adding charcoal to the soil before seeding did not alter the overall plant biomass.
In a study in the Netherlands, adding charcoal to the soil before seeding did not alter grass cover.
In a study in the Netherlands, adding charcoal to the soil before seeding did increase the cover of legumes.
No studies were found that looked at the effects of using organic mulch to restore or create freshwater marshes, freshwater swamps, or brackish/saline swamps.

question_details.query: What management practices, when combined with seeding or planting, have been shown to affect the survival of new plants in grassland restoration?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that winter grazing after sowing seeds resulted in higher survival of cut-leaved cranesbill seedlings [3423]. One study in Germany found that 44% of new seedlings from transplanted pepper saxifrage plants survived over four months [3399].
summary_statements: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that winter grazing after sowing seeds resulted in higher survival of cut-leaved cranesbill seedlings.
One study in Germany found that 44% of new seedlings from transplanted pepper saxifrage plants survived over four months.

question_details.query: How do different mechanical seeding methods like drill seeding, strip seeding, and hydroseeding compare in their effects on grassland vegetation in the US and UK?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Five US-based studies on drill seeding found mixed results, with two of three studies showing no change in plant species richness (3410). One of three US studies indicated that drill seeding increased the density of two sown grass species compared to hand sowing, while another found it boosted the abundance of warm-season grasses (3410). Conversely, two other US studies revealed that drill seeding often led to no change or even a reduction in the abundance of sown plants when compared to hydroseeding or hand sowing (3410). In the UK, one study on strip seeding reported an increase in both grass and forb species richness (3411). However, another UK review noted that strip seeding frequently resulted in the failed introduction of sown species (3411). In the US, a study on hydroseeding demonstrated an increased abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding (3412). Another study in Italy showed that hydroseeding led to an increase in the height of herb species (3412).
summary_statements: Five US-based studies on drill seeding found mixed results.
Two of three US-based studies on drill seeding showed no change in plant species richness.
One of three US studies indicated that drill seeding increased the density of two sown grass species compared to hand sowing.
Another US study found drill seeding boosted the abundance of warm-season grasses.
Two other US studies revealed that drill seeding often led to no change or even a reduction in the abundance of sown plants when compared to hydroseeding or hand sowing.
In the UK, one study on strip seeding reported an increase in both grass and forb species richness.
A UK review noted that strip seeding frequently resulted in the failed introduction of sown species.
In the US, a study on hydroseeding demonstrated an increased abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding.
A study in Italy showed that hydroseeding led to an increase in the height of herb species.

question_details.query: Which site preparation techniques appear most effective at increasing species richness before seeding in European grasslands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A number of studies have found that techniques such as grazing, introducing plant species, hay spreading, and mowing were effective for restoring species-rich grassland [133]. Other studies have found that the restoration of species-rich grassland has resulted in increased plant species richness [133]. Studies have also found that restored grasslands had similar insect abundance and species richness to traditionally managed sites [133]. Another study found that grassland restored on former cropland hosted a similar small mammal species richness when compared to native grassland [2566].
summary_statements: Techniques such as grazing, introducing plant species, hay spreading, and mowing were effective for restoring species-rich grassland.
The restoration of species-rich grassland has resulted in increased plant species richness.
Restored grasslands had similar insect abundance to traditionally managed sites.
Restored grasslands had similar insect species richness to traditionally managed sites.
Grassland restored on former cropland hosted a similar small mammal species richness when compared to native grassland.

question_details.query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of altering seed mix characteristics, such as density or species diversity, for grassland restoration in the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Altering seed mix characteristics for grassland restoration in the USA has been a subject of multiple studies with varied outcomes (3406, 3400, 3432). 

In terms of species diversity, one replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix did not alter plant species richness (3406). However, two replicated, controlled studies in the USA, one of which was randomized, found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix led to an increase in the species richness of sown plants (3406). Regarding plant cover, one of two replicated, controlled studies in the USA, one of which was randomized, reported that increasing the number of species in a seed mix increased the cover of sown plant species, while the other study found no change (3406).

When using seeds from a local source, one replicated study in the USA and Germany showed an increase in vegetation cover over time compared to areas sown with non-native seeds, but a decline in the density of individual plants (3400). Another replicated, randomized, controlled experiment in the USA found that sowing Sandberg bluegrass seeds from a local source did not affect the survival of sown plants compared to non-local varieties (3400). Furthermore, a replicated study in the USA and Italy indicated that sowing grassland seeds from a local source did not change vegetation height compared to sowing non-native grass seeds (3400).

Sowing native grass and forbs has shown some positive results in North American studies. Out of 28 studies, sixteen in Europe, North America, and New Zealand found an increase in overall plant species richness from sowing native grass and forb seeds (3432). Specifically in the USA, one replicated, controlled study found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the species richness of native plants (3432). In terms of abundance, three of eight replicated, controlled studies in Europe and North America found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased overall vegetation cover, biomass, or density (3432). In the USA, two of three replicated, randomized, controlled studies found an increased cover of grass species, and three of four similar studies showed an increased cover or density of forb species (3432). Native plant species cover was also found to be increased in one replicated, controlled study in the USA (3432). Finally, one of two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Germany found that sowing native seeds increased the number of emerged seedlings (3432).
summary_statements: Altering seed mix characteristics for grassland restoration in the USA has been a subject of multiple studies with varied outcomes.
One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix did not alter plant species richness.
Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix led to an increase in the species richness of sown plants.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA reported that increasing the number of species in a seed mix increased the cover of sown plant species.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix resulted in no change to the cover of sown plant species.
One replicated study in the USA and Germany showed an increase in vegetation cover over time when using seeds from a local source compared to areas sown with non-native seeds.
One replicated study in the USA and Germany showed a decline in the density of individual plants when using seeds from a local source compared to areas sown with non-native seeds.
A replicated, randomized, controlled experiment in the USA found that sowing Sandberg bluegrass seeds from a local source did not affect the survival of sown plants compared to non-local varieties.
A replicated study in the USA and Italy indicated that sowing grassland seeds from a local source did not change vegetation height compared to sowing non-native grass seeds.
Sowing native grass and forbs has shown some positive results in North American studies.
Sixteen out of 28 studies in Europe, North America, and New Zealand found an increase in overall plant species richness from sowing native grass and forb seeds.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the species richness of native plants.
Three of eight replicated, controlled studies in Europe and North America found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased overall vegetation cover, biomass, or density.
In the USA, two of three replicated, randomized, controlled studies found an increased cover of grass species from sowing native grass and forb seeds.
In the USA, three of four replicated, randomized, controlled studies showed an increased cover or density of forb species from sowing native grass and forb seeds.
Native plant species cover was found to be increased in one replicated, controlled study in the USA.
One of two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Germany found that sowing native seeds increased the number of emerged seedlings.

question_details.query: How do the outcomes of post-seeding grazing by livestock vary between studies in Europe and the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In Europe, one replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in Italy found that grazing with livestock after sowing seeds increased plant species richness, while a replicated, controlled study in the UK found that it reduced plant species richness compared to cutting vegetation after sowing (3423). Another replicated study in the UK found that grazing with cattle after sowing seeds increased sown species richness but reduced the cover of sown species compared to grazing with sheep (3423). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK also found that winter grazing after sowing resulted in higher survival of cut-leaved cranesbill seedlings (3423). A study in the USA found that grazing with cattle after sowing seeds increased native plant species richness but reduced the cover of native plant species (3423). One replicated, controlled study in Hungary found that grazing with livestock after sowing seeds did not alter the cover of target plant species (3423).
summary_statements: A study in Italy found that grazing with livestock after sowing seeds increased plant species richness.
A study in the UK found that grazing with livestock after sowing seeds reduced plant species richness compared to cutting vegetation after sowing.
A study in the UK found that grazing with cattle after sowing seeds increased sown species richness compared to grazing with sheep.
A study in the UK found that grazing with cattle after sowing seeds reduced the cover of sown species compared to grazing with sheep.
A study in the UK found that winter grazing after sowing resulted in higher survival of cut-leaved cranesbill seedlings.
A study in the USA found that grazing with cattle after sowing seeds increased native plant species richness.
A study in the USA found that grazing with cattle after sowing seeds reduced the cover of native plant species.
A study in Hungary found that grazing with livestock after sowing seeds did not alter the cover of target plant species.

question_details.query: What actions are available to increase the abundance of sown or planted species in grassland restoration projects?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Multiple actions can influence the abundance of sown or planted species in grassland restoration projects. One of two studies in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix increased the cover of sown plant species, while the other study found no change (3406). Another study in Germany found that increasing seed mix species alongside using local seeds increased target plant cover (3406). Additionally, applying herbicide before seeding was found in one UK study to increase sown species richness and in one USA study to increase the cover of sown grass species (3418). A German study also found that pre-seeding herbicide application increased seedling emergence for the majority of wildflower species studied (3418). Sowing seeds in only a part of a site had varied outcomes; a study in the USA noted the appearance of new patches of sown species in unsown areas, whereas a study in the Czech Republic found no change in the cover of sown species (3408).
summary_statements: Multiple actions can influence the abundance of sown or planted species in grassland restoration projects.
One study in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix increased the cover of sown plant species.
Another study in the USA found no change in the cover of sown plant species when the number of species in a seed mix was increased.
A study in Germany found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix alongside using local seeds increased target plant cover.
A UK study found that applying herbicide before seeding increased sown species richness.
A USA study found that applying herbicide before seeding increased the cover of sown grass species.
A German study found that pre-seeding herbicide application increased seedling emergence for the majority of wildflower species studied.
A study in the USA noted the appearance of new patches of sown species in unsown areas when seeds were sown in only a part of a site.
A study in the Czech Republic found no change in the cover of sown species when seeds were sown in only a part of a site.

question_details.query: In European grasslands, how do different soil preparation methods prior to seeding, such as soil disturbance, topsoil removal, and herbicide application, compare in their effects on seedling emergence and survival?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Five studies assessed the impact of soil disturbance on seedling emergence, with four of these studies, located in the USA, Germany, China, and Spain, indicating that disturbing the soil before sowing seeds led to an increase in plant emergence in most cases (3413). In terms of survival, one study in China showed that soil disturbance before seeding increased seedling survival, while another study in Spain found no change (3413). Two studies in the USA on topsoil removal discovered that this method increased the survival of both seedlings and plants (3415).

Regarding herbicide application, one study in Germany reported that its use before seeding enhanced seedling emergence for five out of eight wildflower species (3418). Conversely, a different study in Germany found that transferring large amounts of plant material alongside seeding reduced seedling emergence (3426).
summary_statements: Five studies assessed the impact of soil disturbance on seedling emergence.
Four studies located in the USA, Germany, China, and Spain indicated that disturbing the soil before sowing seeds led to an increase in plant emergence in most cases.
One study in China showed that soil disturbance before seeding increased seedling survival.
A study in Spain found no change in seedling survival following soil disturbance before seeding.
Two studies in the USA on topsoil removal discovered that this method increased the survival of both seedlings and plants.
One study in Germany reported that using herbicide before seeding enhanced seedling emergence for five out of eight wildflower species.
A different study in Germany found that transferring large amounts of plant material alongside seeding reduced seedling emergence.

question_details.query: What is the extent of evidence on how different grassland seeding and planting interventions affect vegetation structure?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For the following interventions, no studies were found that examined their effects on vegetation structure: adding topsoil before seeding/planting (3420), using erosion blankets after seeding/planting (3431), applying herbicide before seeding/planting (3418), irrigating before or after seeding/planting (3430), adding sulphur to soil before seeding/planting (3428), and adding woody debris to protect seeds/plants (3421).
summary_statements: No studies were found that examined the effects of adding topsoil before seeding or planting on vegetation structure.
No studies were found that examined the effects of using erosion blankets after seeding or planting on vegetation structure.
No studies were found that examined the effects of applying herbicide before seeding or planting on vegetation structure.
No studies were found that examined the effects of irrigating before or after seeding or planting on vegetation structure.
No studies were found that examined the effects of adding sulphur to soil before seeding or planting on vegetation structure.
No studies were found that examined the effects of adding woody debris to protect seeds or plants on vegetation structure.

question_details.query: What are the documented impacts of sowing grass seeds on the abundance of native forbs and shrubs in North American grasslands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In North American grasslands, two replicated studies in the USA and Canada found that sowing grass seeds reduced the abundance of shrub species [3397]. Of two replicated studies in the USA and Canada, one found that sowing grass seeds reduced the abundance of native forb species, while the other found no change in their density [3397]. A study in the USA also found that sowing grass seeds at a higher density reduced the cover of native grassland shrubs [3405]. However, another replicated, controlled study in the USA found that sowing grass seeds did not alter the species richness of native plants [3397]. In contrast, sowing native grass and forb seeds together was found to increase the cover or density of forb species in three of four studies in the USA [3432]. Similarly, a study in the USA found that sowing seeds at a higher density increased forb cover [3405].
summary_statements: In North American grasslands, two replicated studies in the USA and Canada found that sowing grass seeds reduced the abundance of shrub species.
Of two replicated studies in the USA and Canada, one found that sowing grass seeds reduced the abundance of native forb species.
Of two replicated studies in the USA and Canada, one study found no change in the density of native forb species.
A study in the USA found that sowing grass seeds at a higher density reduced the cover of native grassland shrubs.
A replicated, controlled study in the USA found that sowing grass seeds did not alter the species richness of native plants.
Sowing native grass and forb seeds together was found to increase the cover or density of forb species in three of four studies in the USA.
A study in the USA found that sowing seeds at a higher density increased forb cover.

question_details.query: What does the evidence from different continents suggest about how sowing different seed typessuch as just grasses versus mixed grass and forbsaffects forb abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from studies in Europe and North America addresses how sowing different seed mixes affects forb abundance. In the Czech Republic and the USA, three out of four studies demonstrated that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the cover or density of forb species (3432). A UK study also found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased forb species richness in 71% of cases (3432). However, one study noted that this effect might be temporary, as the increase in forb cover observed one year after sowing was not present 10 years later when compared to unsown areas (3432). Other factors can also influence forb abundance. A study in the USA found that disturbing soil before sowing forb seeds increased forb cover (3413), and another US study showed that sowing seeds at a higher density also increased forb cover (3405).
summary_statements: Evidence from studies in Europe and North America addresses how sowing different seed mixes affects forb abundance.
In the Czech Republic and the USA, three out of four studies demonstrated that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased the cover or density of forb species.
A UK study found that sowing native grass and forb seeds increased forb species richness in 71% of cases.
One study noted that the effect of increased forb cover after sowing might be temporary.
The increase in forb cover observed one year after sowing was not present 10 years later when compared to unsown areas.
Other factors can also influence forb abundance.
A study in the USA found that disturbing soil before sowing forb seeds increased forb cover.
Another US study showed that sowing seeds at a higher density also increased forb cover.

question_details.query: What are the effects of post-seeding management, specifically mowing versus grazing, on grassland vegetation in the UK?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In the UK, one replicated, controlled study found that cutting vegetation yearly after sowing seeds increased plant species richness when compared to grazing with livestock (3419). Mowing after sowing seeds was also found to increase the richness of sown species in one replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK, and the abundance of sown forb species in a separate UK study (3419). Additionally, a replicated study in the UK determined that cutting sown plots each year and removing the cut vegetation resulted in an increase in the richness of sown grass and forb species compared to cutting without removing the vegetation (3419). However, this practice of cutting and removing vegetation also led to a reduction in the cover of sown grass and forb species (3419).
summary_statements: In the UK, cutting vegetation yearly after sowing seeds increased plant species richness when compared to grazing with livestock.
Mowing after sowing seeds was found to increase the richness of sown species in the UK.
Mowing after sowing seeds was found to increase the abundance of sown forb species in a UK study.

A study in the UK determined that cutting sown plots each year and removing the cut vegetation resulted in an increase in the richness of sown grass and forb species compared to cutting without removing the vegetation.
The practice of cutting and removing vegetation led to a reduction in the cover of sown grass and forb species.
